author: palladia
body: This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/730)

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: This is looking good to me. I want a change to build and test it out myself though as it's a lot of untestable new behavior.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Tested:
- [x] Ctrl-C to kill single-line (doesn't yank, should it?)
- [x] Ctrl-C to exit multi-line
- [x] Ctrl-C is passed to running commands
- [x] Ctrl-K works, and is yankable with Ctrl-Y
- [x] Ctrl-Y can yank anywhere
- [x] Ctrl-L clears, and keeps current line (even in multi-line)
- [x] Ctrl-R reverse searches
- [x] Ctrl-R incrementally searches
- [x] Ctrl-R cycles backward through matches
- [x] Ctrl-R reports when there are no more matches to be found
- [ ] Ctrl-R text does not match PSReadLine
- [ ] Ctrl-S does _not_ cycle forward through history search
- [x] `$Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor` is customizable (#730)
- [ ] `$Host.UI.RawUI.ForegroundColor` is _not_ customizable
- [ ] Ctrl-Home does nothing, should it?
- [ ] Ctrl-End does nothing, should it?
- [ ] Ctrl-Home in PSReadLine on Windows moves to the top of the buffer
- [ ] Ctrl-End in PSReadLine on Windows moves to the end of the buffer

---

Reviewed 4 of 4 files at r1.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 10 unresolved discussions.

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/main.cs, line 576 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZw1eUSzj_r2L44pg9:-KDZw1eVXq_w1FIC3x94:1283787941) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/main.cs#L576)):_
Just some style notes:
- We can (and should) prefer `var` over a type; let the compiler deduce it to make refactoring easy later
- We should avoid `this.` as it is (almost) never necessary
- `string` vs `String` should be consistent
- We need to write some style documentation for all of PowerShell...

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/main.cs, line 624 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZwZCOdPpMn6lCoqYR:-KDZwZCPTR3KQEPZdrzD:176696177) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/main.cs#L624)):_
Is `ToString()` necessary? Shouldn't WriteLine, taking a string, implicitly do this? I don't know.

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 621 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZy5DOCfBHtVLLBeXc:-KDZy5DOCfBHtVLLBeXd:1059463745) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L621)):_

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 640 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZy_kQkJOFHM8HsuJY:-KDZy_kQkJOFHM8HsuJZ:-1016250117) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L640)):_

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Just saw this:

```
/home/andrew/src/PowerShell-Linux |-/ (reverse-i-search)'c': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'                              (failed reverse-i-search)'co': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'                      (failed reverse-i-search)'con': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'                     (failed reverse-i-search)'cons': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'                    (failed reverse-i-search)'conso': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'                   (failed reverse-i-search)'consol': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'                  (failed reverse-i-search)'console': $Host.UI.RawUI.BackgroundColor = 'Black'
```

Only it was wrapping at my Window border. Is it fixable?

_Comments from the [review on Reviewable.io](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-:-KD_1Y-ZQAhZ_cpQvL0C:-1164215244)_

<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

comments.author: palladia
comments.body:
To answer some of your concerns:
1.  Ctrl-R text.  I took the text from bash, since it has a similar one-line behavior.  
2.  Ctrl-S.  I mentioned this at stand up, that it may not make sense to implement forward search. Everyone agreed.
3.  Foreground color is not customizable?  Please elaborate.  It seems to work for me.
4.  Ctrl-Home and Ctrl-End.  I didn't see a requirement on this.  It wasn't the intention to implement every key shortcut. 
5.  Console colors default to -1 at startup.  Once you override, the -1 goes away.  If you have default value from profile, you also will not see -1.

comments.author: palladia
comments.body:
_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/main.cs, line 624 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZwZCOdPpMn6lCoqYR:-KD_4UfijoyxI6wssBSW:171438166) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/main.cs#L624)):_
It was necessary because compiler complained that it could not convert from PSObject to String, if I remember correctly.

<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
1. We're trying to emulate PSReadLine, not Bash
2. Ctrl-S should be implemented since PSReadLine does so, but this can be done separately
3. Oh; I expected it to change the color of the text in the prompt; it just changes cmdlet output color
4. I don't mind them being unimplemented; it just looked like you had
5. They appear to be set on Windows, so we should do the same

---

comments.body:

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 165 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZxbb-1CatRtPc0wiY:-KD_6K828V27B284pPfP:1874724761) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L165)):_
Nothing here is supposed to throw.  And if something does throw, how should we handle it?  Abort the input like ctrl-c?  In theory, no valid command will get executed, so not changing TreatControlCAsInput to false would not be catastrophic .

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 214 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KD_-ZySx9LjuRtIY2I6:-KD_8Hhc-MzmL2ls_qr5:-776952309) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L214)):_
I could've implemented these bool's as class members.  Not sure if it's worth changing though.

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 615 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZxyCP7ONfUQOHccw-:-KD_8gWNagHh9zuwlSyO:-1546429632) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L615)):_
Yes,  I could use that.  Wrote these before the migration to ui.write.

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 617 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZyHRqUBIkElX3JvqN:-KD_8tujwhtk90Uv5DSS:-723747192) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L617)):_
Do we have to match PSReadline?

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 621 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZy5DOCfBHtVLLBeXc:-KD_94cfbe3O-JYNtFDN:-2000117650) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L621)):_
"much preferred" because?  Not sure it's a big difference, but I will change it.

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 640 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZy_kQkJOFHM8HsuJY:-KD_9WJKP4cwLXLH96Kx:301318996) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L640)):_
It's not clear where forward search starts at, and native Window PS basically does nothing.  I brought this up at stand up, and it's agreed that the lack of definition of where "current line" is makes implementing this a difficult thing, and not worth the effort now.

---

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 698 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZzFhhrQsriJQSZfe1:-KD_A9a-rzI02GDRsTWt:-1345986946) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L698)):_
Again, do we have to match PSReadline?  I chose this implementation because it's fairly simple, and can be done in one-line.  I don't claim this is a full-featured implementation of reverse-search.  In fact, PSReadLine's implementation does a lot more, especially when it comes to multi-line commands.  I chose not to spend days to support multi-line recall right now.  

---

comments.author: palladia
comments.body:
I don't care if we emulate PSReadLine, or Bash.  Had I chosen PSReadLine, someone might say that we should emulate Bash.  Is there a requirement that we should match PSReadLine exactly?

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 640 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZy_kQkJOFHM8HsuJY:-KD_ERkUj9EQi0q84P2v:1448018586) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L640)):_
Forward search starts where backward search left off, literally just reverse direction from current result. If no reverse search was done, it is a no-op.

_[src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs, line 640 [r1]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/powershell/powershell/730#-KDZy_kQkJOFHM8HsuJY:-KD_FYBAPah-NwYNFVsm:-599382904) ([raw file](https://github.com/powershell/powershell/blob/dc6691684e93686cde9fab6c029d9a60a800e060/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L640)):_
Except that to go from reverse search to forward search, you need to type "Enter".  And once you type "Enter", the "current" line is now the last line, and forward search becomes meaningless.

comments.body: This is good, going to merge. We still have some open questions, but I'll create separate issues (some of the require more discussion than we should do here).

title: MegaPatch that includes all of #717, plus RawUI fixes
